Line 61: Line 61:  
As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may, for instance, turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability, or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meeting a number which substantiate noteworthiness in combination.
 
As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may, for instance, turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability, or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meeting a number which substantiate noteworthiness in combination.
    −
By the same token, argument based on loopholes should not be accorded any weight. For instance, it is possible to imagine an article written about a "book" packaged by a manufacturer with every sample of a particular product that is not an instruction manual but has no independent notability, despite that it could be deemed to have "sold" a million copies. Common sense and logic should be the touchstones of a deletion discussion.

Line 55: Line 55:      
====Academic books====
 
====Academic books====
−
Academic books serve a very different function and come to be [[Academic publishing|published]] through very different processes than do books intended for the general public. They are often highly specialized, have small printing runs, and may only be available in specialized libraries and bookstores. For these reasons, the bulk of standards delineated previously for mainstream books are incompatible in the academic bailiwick. Again, common sense should prevail. In that case, notability should rely on the reputation of the academic press publishing it<ref>Publication by a prominent academic press should be accorded far more weight than the analogous benchmark defined for publication of mainstream book by well know commercial publishers, by virtue of the ''non''-commercial nature of such presses, and the [[peer review]] process that must be passed before publication is allowed to go forward. See [[:Category:University book publishers|university book publishers]] for a partial list of such presses. Note that because a large portion of (en.)Wikipedia articles are written by English speaking people from English speaking nations, this list currently betrays an admittedly U.S./U.K/Canada-centric makeup.</ref>, how widely the book is cited by other academic publications or in the media<ref>A book's subject may be so specialized, such as in the esoteric math or physics spheres, that only a few hundred (or less) people in the world are situated to understand and comment on the material.</ref>, how influential the book is considered to be in its specialty area and whether it is taught or required reading in a number of reputable educational institutions.

This page gives some rough guidelines<ref>Try not to apply ''guidelines'' reflexively; as if they are written in stone. All deletion discussions should be approached on a case-by-case basis, with an eye toward the peculiar circumstances presented. Keep in mind that subjects are not notable ''because'' they meet a particular standard, rather things are notable because of their impact, influence, fame, etc., and the standards are an attempt to catalogue what notable subjects share so that we can ''recognize'' that notability.</ref> intended to be used by Wikipedia editors to decide whether a book should or should not have an article on Wikipedia.

This page gives some rough guidelines<ref>Try not to apply ''guidelines'' reflexively; as if they are written in stone. All deletion discussions should be approached on a case-by-case basis, with an eye toward the peculiar circumstances presented. Keep in mind that subjects are not notable ''because'' they meet a particular standard, rather things are notable because of their impact, influence, fame, etc., and the standards are an attempt to catalogue what notable subjects share so that we can ''recognize'' that notability.</ref> intended to be used by Wikipedia editors to decide whether a book should or should not have an article on Wikipedia. Note that failing to satisfy these notability guidelines is '''not''' a [[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|criterion for speedy deletion]].
−   −
'''Important note''': Failing to satisfy these notability guidelines is '''not''' a [[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|criterion for speedy deletion]].
       
Many Wikipedians are wholly averse to the use of Wikipedia for [[Wikipedia:spam|advertising]] and promotion of non-notable material, and that [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not|Wikipedia articles must not be vehicles for advertisement]] is an official policy of long standing. A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[WP:OR|no original research]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]].<ref>Another core policy all articles must adhere to is to be written from a [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. However, it is general consensus that even the most blatantly "point of view" articles should not be nominated for deletion solely on this basis. Instead, they should either be rewritten to remove the bias, or tagged for cleanup to resolve the issue.</ref> Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.

A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[WP:OR|no original research]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]].<ref>Another core policy all articles must adhere to is to be written from a [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. However, it is general consensus that even the most blatantly "point of view" articles should not be nominated for deletion solely on this basis. Instead, they should either be rewritten to remove the bias, or tagged for cleanup to resolve the issue.</ref> Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.

Line 45: Line 47:  
====The "Google test"====
 
====The "Google test"====
 
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a positive notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such as a few dozen to none), that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].
 
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a positive notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such as a few dozen to none), that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].

Note, though, that the Harry Potter novels are an international phenomenon, having sold more than 300 million copies worldwide, and have been translated into 63 languages as of October 2005.<ref>BBC (2005). BBC News article: ''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/4308548.stm Global Potter sales top 300m mark]''. Retrieved July 2, 2006.</ref>
  +   ⚫
====Non-contemporary books====
  ⚫
From a pragmatic standpoint, the vast majority of books upon which articles are written which invite a notability judgment call, and which find their way to [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]] are from the modern era. Nevertheless, the notability of books written or published much earlier may occasionally be disputed and the criteria proposed above intended primarily for modern books may not be as suitable. We suggest instead a more common sense approach which considers whether the book has been widely cited or written about, whether it has been recently reprinted, the fame that the book enjoyed in the past and its place in the [[history of literature]].
  +   ⚫
====Academic books====
  ⚫
Academic books serve a very different function and come to be [[Academic publishing|published]] through very different processes than do books intended for the general public. They are often highly specialized, have small printing runs, and may only be available in specialized libraries and bookstores. For these reasons, the bulk of standards delineated previously for mainstream books are incompatible in the academic bailiwick. Again, common sense should prevail. In that case, notability should rely on the reputation of the academic press publishing it?<ref>Publication by a prominent academic press should be accorded far more weight than the analogous benchmark defined for publication of mainstream book by well know commercial publishers, by virtue of the ''non''-commercial nature of such presses, and the [[peer review]] process that must be passed before publication is allowed to go forward. See [[:Category:University book publishers|university book publishers]] for a partial list of such presses. Note that because a large portion of (en.)Wikipedia articles are written by English speaking people from English speaking nations, this list currently betrays an admittedly U.S./U.K/Canada-centric makeup.</ref>, how widely the book is cited by other academic publications or in the media<ref>A book's subject may be so specialized, such as in the esoteric math or physics spheres, that only a few hundred (or less) people in the world are situated to understand and comment on the material.</ref>, how influential the book is considered to be in its specialty area and whether it is taught or required reading in a number of reputable educational institutions?

  ⚫

  −

  −
* How well known is the author in general, and how well know is the author in the field of interest covered by the book? Reference [[Wikipedia:Notability (academics)]].
  −
* How influential is the book considered in its specialty area?
  −
* Is the book known to be taught or required reading in a number of reputable educational institutions?

==Criteria (pre-1900)==
  −
From a pragmatic standpoint, the vast majority of books upon which articles are written which invite a notability judgment call, and which find their way to [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]] are from the modern era. Nevertheless, the notability of books written or published prior to 1900 may occasionally be disputed and the criteria proposed above for more modern books may not be as suitable. We suggest instead a more common sense approach:
      −
* Has the book been widely-cited/written about in the present?
  −
* Has the book been reprinted during modern times?
  −
* What degree of fame has the book enjoyed in the past?
  −
* How widely distributed was the book?
  −
* Was the book written by a person notable enough for a Wikipedia article pursuant to our [[Wikipedia:Notability (people)|guidelines for notability of people]]?
  −
* Is the book widely considered today as important in the [[history of literature]]?
  −
''Contrarily'':
  −
* Is the book only known to the article's creator?
  −
* Is the book only mentioned in other publications of the time with no present copies extant?

All deletion discussions should be approached on a case-by-case basis, with an eye toward the peculiar circumstances presented. Keep in mind that subjects are not notable ''because'' they meet a particular standard, rather things are notable because of their impact, influence, fame, etc., and the standards are an attempt to catalogue what notable subjects share so that we can ''recognize'' that notability.</ref> intended to be used by Wikipedia editors to decide whether a book should or should not have an article on Wikipedia.

Line 91: Line 91:      
==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
−
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character or thing from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist— especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
+
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character or thing from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist— especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' ''[[A Clockwork Orange]]'' does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

In this regard, it should be especially noted that self-publication and/or publication by a [[vanity press]] is indicia, but not determinative of ''non''-notability. Exceptions do exist. Taking the preceding threshold section into account, it should be noted that many vanity press books are both assigned ISBN numbers and may be listed in a national library such as the Library of Congress, as well as are amenable to being found through a [http://books.google.com/ Google book search].

As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may, for instance, turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability, or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meeting a number which substantiate noteworthiness in combination.
 
As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may, for instance, turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability, or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meeting a number which substantiate noteworthiness in combination.
    −
By the same token, argument based on loopholes should not be accorded any weight. For instance, it is possible to imagine an article written about a "book" packaged by a manufacturer with every sample of a particular product that is not an instruction manual but has no independent notability, despite that it could be deemed to have "sold" a million copies. Likewise, it would be possible for a self-published author, whose book is completely unknown, to translate it into 4 languages just so it would meet the letter of the relevant translation standard. As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may, for instance, turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability, or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meeting a number which substantiate noteworthiness in combination.

By the same token, argument based on loopholes should not be accorded any weight. For instance, it is possible to imagine an article written about a "book" packaged by a manufacturer with every sample of a particular product that is not an instruction manual but has no independent notability, despite that it could be deemed to have "sold" a million copies. Likewise, it would be possible for a self-published author, whose book is completely unknown, to translate it into 10 languages just so it would meet the letter of the relevant translation standard. Commonsense and logic should be the touchstones of a deletion discussion.

Line 91: Line 91:      
==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
−
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character or thing from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
+
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character or thing from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist— especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
 
For more detailed guidelines regarding articles about fiction, see [[Wikipedia:Notability (fiction)]].

Line 79: Line 79:      
==Criteria (academic books)==
 
==Criteria (academic books)==
  +
Academic books, though they share some similarities in form, serve a very different function and come to be [[Academic publishing|published]] through very different processes than do books intended for general consumption.
      +
Academic books are often highly specialized, have small printing runs, are not sold in most bookstores, and may only be available in specialized libraries. For these reasons, the bulk of standards delineated previously for mainstream books are incompatible in the academic bailiwick.
  +   +
Like the criteria for pre-1900 books, a more common sense approach is suggested. With this proviso, some suggestions for appropriate notability inquiries follow:
  +
* Is the book printed by a reputable or well known academic press?<ref>Publication by a prominent academic press should be accorded far more weight than the analogous benchmark defined for publication of mainstream book by well know commercial publishers, by virtue of the ''non''-commercial nature of such presses, and the [[peer review]] process that must be passed before publication is allowed to go forward.</ref> (See [[university book publishers]] for a partial list of such presses.<ref>Because a large portion of (en.)Wikipedia articles are written by English speaking people from English speaking nations, this list currently betrays an admittedly U.S./U.K/Canada-centric makeup.</ref>
  +
* How widely cited is the book by other publications/media? For this inquiry, be especially mindful of how specialized the book's subject is and, thus, how circumscribed both the book's audience and the body of literature in the area may be.<ref>A book's subject may be so specialized, such as in the esoteric math or physics spheres, that only a few hundred (or less) people in the world are situated to understand and comment on the material.</ref>
  +
* How well known is the author in general, and how well know is the author in the field of interest covered by the book?
  +
* How influential is the book considered in its specialty area?

Line 78: Line 78:      
==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
−
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
+
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character or thing from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[WP:OR|no original research]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]<ref>Another core policy all articles must adhere to is to be written from a [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. Instead, they should either be rewritten to remove the bias, or tagged for cleanup to resolve the issue.</ref> Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.

Many Wikipedians are wholly averse to the use of Wikipedia for [[Wikipedia:spam|advertising]] and promotion of non-notable material, and that [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not|Wikipedia articles must not be vehicles for advertisement]] is an official policy of long standing. A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[WP:OR|no original research]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]].<ref>Another core policy all articles must adhere to is to be written from a [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. However, it is general consensus that even the most blatantly "point of view" articles should not be nominated for deletion solely on this basis. Instead, they should either be rewritten to remove the bias, or tagged for cleanup to resolve the issue.</ref> Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.
     
Please note that the failure to meet any of these criteria does not mean an article ''must'' be deleted; likewise, the meeting of any of these criteria does not mean that an article ''must'' be kept. These are merely rules of thumb which some editors choose to keep in mind when deciding whether or not to keep an article that is listed on [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]]. Note also that not only must articles adhere to Wikipedia's policy on [[WP:V|verifiability]], but this naturally apply to ''claims'' of notability; it is not enough to simply assert that a book meets a criterion without substantiating that claim with [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]].

Note, though, that the Harry Potter novels are an international phenomenon, having sold more than 300 million copies worldwide, and have been translated into 63 languages as of October 2005.<ref>BBC (2005).   +   +
== Flexibility ==
  +
As noted in the introduction, these are not intended, nor should they be used as hidebound rules which an article either fails or passes. Deletion debates may turn up criteria not covered here which reasonable people can agree substantiate notability. Or a book may not meet any single criteria, but come substantially close to meet a number. By the same token, argument based on loopholes should not be accorded any weight. For instance is is possible to imagine an article written about a "book" packaged by a manufacturer with every sample of a particular product that is not an instruction manual but has no independent notability, despite that it could be deemed to have "sold" a million copies. Commonsense and logic should be used as the touchstones of a deletion discussion.

Since [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a crystal ball|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]] articles about books that are not yet published are generally discouraged unless multiple independent sources provide strong evidence that the book is widely anticipated and unless the title of the book and its approximate date of publication have been made public.
 
Since [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a crystal ball|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]] articles about books that are not yet published are generally discouraged unless multiple independent sources provide strong evidence that the book is widely anticipated and unless the title of the book and its approximate date of publication have been made public.
    −
In exceptional cases these standards may be relaxed for very highly anticipated forthcoming books. For example, in 2005, an article was created on [[Harry Potter book seven]], which then had no confirmed title or release date scheduled. Note, though, that the Harry Potter novels are an international phenomenon, having sold more than 300 million copies worldwide, and have been translated into 63 languages as of October 2005.{{fn|6}}
+

====The "Google test"====
 
====The "Google test"====
−
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a positve notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such as a few dozen to none), that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].
+

Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].

==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
 
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
 
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. Exceptions do, of course, exist, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[WP:OR|no original research]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.

Line 43: Line 43:      
====The "Google test"====
 
====The "Google test"====
−
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a positve notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such a few dozen) to none, that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].
+

Line 40: Line 40:      
====Online bookstores====
 
====Online bookstores====
−
It should be noted that a book's listing at online bookstores such as[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/ Barnes&Noble.com] or [http://www.amazon.com Amazon.com] is not by itself an indication of notability as both websites are non-exclusionary, including large numbers of vanity press publications. There is no present agreement on how high or low a book must fall on Amazon's sale's rank listing (in the "product details" section for a book's listing) in order to provide evidence of its notability, ''vel non''.
+
It should be noted that a book's listing at online bookstores such as [http://www.barnesandnoble.com/ Barnes&Noble.com] or [http://www.amazon.com Amazon.com] is not by itself an indication of notability as both websites are non-exclusionary, including large numbers of vanity press publications. There is no present agreement on how high or low a book must fall on Amazon's sale's rank listing (in the "product details" section for a book's listing) in order to provide evidence of its notability, ''vel non''.
     
====The "Google test"====
 
====The "Google test"====
−
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a postivie notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such a few dozen) to none, that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. However, large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].
+
A simple google (or other search engine) search may function as an essential tool for finding reliable sources, but simply citing the number of hits returned, if over a few hundred, is fraught with problems and has been deprecated as a positve notability test. For example, once the "unique" count goes over a few hundred, it becomes difficult or impossible to determine just how high it should be. If the unique count is extremely low (such a few dozen) to none, that may be a sign that there really is only a small number of listings for the subject on the Internet. Large numbers of hits are often deceptive; a single web site can account for hundreds of thousands of hits. For more information, see [[Wikipedia:Search engine test]].
     
====Self-interested creation====
 
====Self-interested creation====
−
It should always weigh against an article's inclusion if the author or other interested party is the creator of the Wikipedia article. See [[WP:AUTO]].
+
It should always weigh against an article's inclusion if the author or other interested party is the creator of the Wikipedia article. See [[Wikipedia:Autobiography]].
     
====Not yet published books====
 
====Not yet published books====

Line 31: Line 31:      
===Other considerations===
 
===Other considerations===
  +
====Threshold standards====
−    
Books should have at a minimum an [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN number]] (for books published after 1966), be available at a dozen or more libraries and be catalogued by its country of origin's official or ''de facto'' [[national library]]. For example, in the United States books are catalogued by the [[Library of Congress]]; United Kingdom at the [[British Library]]; Australia at the [[National Library of Australia]]; Canada at the [[Library and Archives Canada]]; France at the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]], China at the [[National Library Board]]; Argentina at [[Biblioteca Nacional de la República Argentina]]; and in India at the [[National Library of India]]. For a complete list, see [[List of national libraries]].
 
Books should have at a minimum an [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN number]] (for books published after 1966), be available at a dozen or more libraries and be catalogued by its country of origin's official or ''de facto'' [[national library]]. For example, in the United States books are catalogued by the [[Library of Congress]]; United Kingdom at the [[British Library]]; Australia at the [[National Library of Australia]]; Canada at the [[Library and Archives Canada]]; France at the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]], China at the [[National Library Board]]; Argentina at [[Biblioteca Nacional de la República Argentina]]; and in India at the [[National Library of India]]. For a complete list, see [[List of national libraries]].
     
However, these are exclusionary criteria rather than inclusionary; this ''does not mean'' that a book which meets these criteria is notable, whereas a book which does not meet these threshold standards most likely is not.
 
However, these are exclusionary criteria rather than inclusionary; this ''does not mean'' that a book which meets these criteria is notable, whereas a book which does not meet these threshold standards most likely is not.
      +
====Self-publication====
−
On this issue, it should be especially noted that self-publication and/or publication by a [[vanity press]] is indicia, but not determinative of ''non''-notability, and many vanity press books are both assigned ISBN numbers and may be listed in a national library such as the Library of Congress, as well as are amenable to being found through a [http://books.google.com/ Google book search]. In this same vein, publication by a major publishing house is indicia, but not determinative of notability.
+
In this regard, it should be especially noted that self-publication and/or publication by a [[vanity press]] is indicia, but not determinative of ''non''-notability, and many vanity press books are both assigned ISBN numbers and may be listed in a national library such as the Library of Congress, as well as are amenable to being found through a [http://books.google.com/ Google book search]. In this same vein, publication by a major publishing house is indicia, but not determinative of notability.
  +   +
====Online bookstores====
  ⚫

There is no present agreement on how high or low a book must fall on Amazon's sale's rank listing (in the "product details" section for a book's listing) in order to provide evidence of its notability, ''vel non''.

Line 67: Line 67:      
The following books meet the notability criteria described above:
 
The following books meet the notability criteria described above:
  +
* [[Chicken Soup for the Soul]] is notable since it sold more than 2 million copies. It was also given extensive coverage in english-language media.
  +
* The books featured on [[Oprah's Book Club]] are all notable if only by the amount of sales that the club generates. Moreover, most of these books were already notable and most certainly were the subject of intensive media coverage following their apperance on the club.
  +
* [[The End of History and the Last Man]] is notable. It generated heated debate and has been quoted repeatedly, particularly during the months following September 2001. It has also been translated in many languages.
  +
* [[The Tin Drum]] (1959) is notable. It is considered one of the most important novels by the german [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[Günter Grass]]. It was adapted for the big-screen and the resulting movie won the [[Palme d'or]] at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].
  +
* [[Madame Bovary]], first published in 1856, meets the criteria for books written between 1750 and the modern era. It was a bestseller at the time and is one of the most famous french novels of the [[19th century]].

==Criteria (antiquity)==
  +
From a pragmatic standpoint, the vast majority of books upon which articles are written which invite a notability judgment call, and which find their way to [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]] are from the modern era.
  +   +
While judgment calls must be made when assessing any book's notability, nevertheless, sufficiently ancient books, which we we will define here as written more than 250 years ago (approximately 1750), are generally axiomatically notable by virtue of their survival to the present.
  +   +
For books written during the 1750 to the modern era, a common sense approach is suggested:
  +   +
* Has the book been widely-cited/written about in the present?
  +
* Has the book been reprinted during modern times?
  +
* What degree of fame has the book enjoyed in the past?
  +

Books should have at a minimum an [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN number]] (for books published after 1966), be available at a dozen or more libraries and be catalogued by the [[Library of Congress]] or at the [[British Library]] in the case of the United Kingdom. However, these are exclusionary criteria rather than inclusionary; this ''does not mean'' that a book which meet these criteria is notable, whereas a book which does not meet these threshold standards is very likely not.
     
On this tack, it should be especially noted that self-publication and/or publication by a [[vanity press]] is indicia, but not determinative of ''non''-notability, and many vanity press books are both assigned ISBN numbers and are listed by the Library of Congress as well as are amenable to being found through a [http://books.google.com/ Google book search]. In this same vein, publication by a major publishing house is indicia, but not determinative of notability.

Line 39: Line 39:  
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. There are notable exceptions to this, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

* {{fnb|1}} Try not to apply ''guidelines'' reflexively; as if they are written in stone. Finally, be careful to check that the author, publisher, agent, vendor. etc. of a particular book are in no way interested in any third party source.

* {{fnb|3}} "Non-trivial" normally excludes blogs, online periodicals, personal websites and other media that are not ''themselves'' notable. An analysis of the manner of treatment is crucial as well; Slashdot.org for example is notable, but postings by members of the public to that forum on a subject do not share the imprimatur of that site. Finally, be careful to check that the author, publisher, agent, vendor. etc. of a particular book are in no way interested in any third party source.
 
* {{fnb|4}} Self-promotion and product placement are not the routes to having an encyclopedia article. The published works must be ''someone else'' writing about the book. (See [[Wikipedia:Autobiography]] for the verifiability and neutrality problems that affect material where the subject of the article itself is the source of the material). The barometer of notability is whether people ''independent'' of the subject itself (or of its author, publisher, vendor or agent) have actually considered the book notable enough that they have written and published non-trivial works that focus upon it.

Books should have at a minimum an [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN number]], be available at a dozen or more libraries and be catalogued by the [[Library of Congress]]. Line 38: Line 38:  
==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
 
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. There are notable exceptions to this, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].

* {{fnb|1}} Try not to apply ''guidelines'' reflexively; as if they are written in stone. * {{fnb|3}} Non-trivial normally excludes blogs, online periodicals, personal websites and other media that are not ''themselves'' notable. An analysis of the manner off treatment is crucial as well; Slashdot.org for example is notable, but postings by members of the public to that forum on a subject do not share the imprimatur of that site. Finally, be careful to check that the author, publisher, agent, vendor. etc. of a particular book are in no way interested in any third party source.
 
* {{fnb|4}} Self-promotion and product placement are not the routes to having an encyclopedia article. The published works must be ''someone else'' writing about the book. (See [[Wikipedia:Autobiography]] for the verifiability and neutrality problems that affect material where the subject of the article itself is the source of the material). The barometer of notability is whether people ''independent'' of the subject itself (or of its author, publisher, vendor or agent) have actually considered the book notable enough that they have written and published non-trivial works that focus upon it.

This page gives some rough guidelines{{fn|1}} which Wikipedia editors use to decide if a book should have an article on Wikipedia.
+
This page gives some rough guidelines{{fn|1}} intended to be used by Wikipedia editors to decide whether a book should or should not have an article on Wikipedia.
     
'''Important note''': Failing to satisfy the notability guidelines is '''not''' a [[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|criterion for speedy deletion]]. An article that fails to even ''claim'' that the subject of the article is notable can be speedily deleted under criterion A7, however. A mere claim of notability, even if contested, may avoid deletion under A7 and require a full [[WP:AfD|Article for Deletion]] process to determine if the subject of the article is notable.
 
'''Important note''': Failing to satisfy the notability guidelines is '''not''' a [[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|criterion for speedy deletion]]. An article that fails to even ''claim'' that the subject of the article is notable can be speedily deleted under criterion A7, however. A mere claim of notability, even if contested, may avoid deletion under A7 and require a full [[WP:AfD|Article for Deletion]] process to determine if the subject of the article is notable.
    −
Many Wikipedians are wholly averse to the use of Wikipedia for [[Wikipedia:spam|advertising]] and promotion of non-notable material, and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not|Wikipedia articles are not advertisements]] is an official policy of long standing. A number of articles about certain books have also been found to be in violation of other important Wikipedia policies such as [[WP:NOT|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]], [[WP:NOT|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]] and [[WP:NOT|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. Advertising is either [[Wikipedia:cleanup|cleaned up]] to adhere to the [[Wikipedia:neutral point of view|neutral point of view]] or deleted. In the latter case, it may be first [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] and if proposed deletion is rejected, and article may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus, of which this guideline is a part.
+
Many Wikipedians are wholly averse to the use of Wikipedia for [[Wikipedia:spam|advertising]] and promotion of non-notable material, and that [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not|Wikipedia articles must not be vehicles for advertisement]] is an official policy of long standing. A number of other relevant policies which all articles must comport with are: [[WP:V|verifiability]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a soapbox|Wikipedia is not a soapbox]]; [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information]]; and [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. Where articles fail to encompass these policy considerations and others, they may be [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] or may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:Notability]] to come to consensus. This guideline is a part of that notability standard.
     
Please note that the failure to meet any of these criteria does not mean an article ''must'' be deleted; likewise, the meeting of any of these criteria does not mean that an article ''must'' be kept. These are merely rules of thumb which some editors choose to keep in mind when deciding whether or not to keep an article that is on [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]].

Advertising is either [[Wikipedia:cleanup|cleaned up]] to adhere to the [[Wikipedia:neutral point of view|neutral point of view]] or deleted. In the latter case, it may be first [[Wikipedia:Proposed deletion|proposed for deletion]] and if proposed deletion is rejected, and article may be more formally listed at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]], where Wikipedia editors apply the criteria outlined at [[Wikipedia:notablity]] to come to consensus, of which this guideline is a part.
     
Please note that the failure to meet any of these criteria does not mean an article ''must'' be deleted; likewise, the meeting of any of these criteria does not mean that an article ''must'' be kept. These are merely rules of thumb which some editors choose to keep in mind when deciding whether or not to keep an article that is on [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]].
 
Please note that the failure to meet any of these criteria does not mean an article ''must'' be deleted; likewise, the meeting of any of these criteria does not mean that an article ''must'' be kept. These are merely rules of thumb which some editors choose to keep in mind when deciding whether or not to keep an article that is on [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]].

==Derivative articles==
 
==Derivative articles==
−
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and despite that the book may be notable, that derivative article may not be. There are notable exceptions to this, especially in the case of very famous novels. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
+
It is a general consensus on Wikipedia that articles should not be split and split again into ever more minutia of detail treatment, with each split normally lowering the level of notability. What this means is that while a book may be notable, it is not normally advisable to have a separate article on a character from the book, and it is often the case that despite the book being manifestly notable, a derivative article from it is not. There are notable exceptions to this, especially in the case of very famous books. For example few would argue that [[Anthony Burgess]]' [[A Clockwork Orange]] does not warrant a 'subarticle' on its protagonist, [[Alex DeLarge]].
 
[[WP:FICT|More detailed guidelines]] regarding articles about fiction can also be consulted.

Books should have at a minimum an [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN number]], be available at a dozen or more libraries and be catalogued by the [[Library of Congress]]. However, this is exlusionary criteria rather than inclusionary; this ''does not mean'' that a book which meet these criteria is notable.
    −
On this tack, it should be especially noted that self-publication and/or publication by a [[vanity press]] is indicia, but not determinative of non-notability, and many vanity presses books are both assigned ISBN numbers and are listed by the Library of Congress as well as are amenable to being found through a [http://books.google.com/ Google book search].
